items.title: Upgrading from pyldap 2.4.45 to 3.0.0 breaks the package
items.body:
Somehow this dummy package breaks things for me when I upgrade from 2.4.45 to 3.0.0 I can no longer use the proper imports.

```bash
~/temp$ virtualenv -p python3 venv
Already using interpreter /usr/bin/python3
Using base prefix '/usr'
New python executable in /home/ckreuzberger/temp/venv/bin/python3
Also creating executable in /home/ckreuzberger/temp/venv/bin/python
Installing setuptools, pkg_resources, pip, wheel...source venv/bin/adone.

~/temp$ source venv/bin/activate
(venv) ~/temp$ pip install "pyldap<3"
Collecting pyldap<3
Requirement already satisfied: setuptools in ./venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages (from pyldap<3)
Installing collected packages: pyldap
Successfully installed pyldap-2.4.45
(venv) ~/temp$ pip install "pyldap>=3" --upgrade
Collecting pyldap>=3
Collecting python-ldap>=3.0.0b1 (from pyldap>=3)
Collecting pyasn1>=0.3.7 (from python-ldap>=3.0.0b1->pyldap>=3)
  Using cached pyasn1-0.4.2-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Collecting pyasn1-modules>=0.1.5 (from python-ldap>=3.0.0b1->pyldap>=3)
  Using cached pyasn1_modules-0.2.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: pyasn1, pyasn1-modules, python-ldap, pyldap
  Found existing installation: pyldap 2.4.45
    Uninstalling pyldap-2.4.45:
      Successfully uninstalled pyldap-2.4.45
Successfully installed pyasn1-0.4.2 pyasn1-modules-0.2.1 pyldap-3.0.0 python-ldap-3.0.0

(venv) ~/temp$ python
Python 3.5.2 (default, Nov 23 2017, 16:37:01) 
[GCC 5.4.0 20160609] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ldap
>>> ldap.SCOPE_SUBTREE
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: module 'ldap' has no attribute 'SCOPE_SUBTREE'
>>> 
```

However, if I create a completely new virtualenv and run ``pip install pyldap`` (which installs version 3.0) it works fine.

For comparison, this is what my site-packages/ldap/ directory looks like when I upgrade:

![screenshot_2018-03-22_08-17-39](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18396259/37756369-87b041de-2da9-11e8-892d-ec8e3b9760d7.png)

And this is what it looks like when I run a completely new installation:

![screenshot_2018-03-22_08-18-46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18396259/37756408-aa13ba94-2da9-11e8-99f1-da3d98ea9388.png)

So for some reason separately uninstalling pyldap==2.4.45 and then installing pyldap==3.0.0 (which acts as a dummy package) works, but doing a ``pip install pyldap --upgrade" does not work.

Is there any way to fix this within the ``setup.py`` script?

items.title: Release 3.0.0 (as a dummy package)
items.body:
python-ldap 3.0.0 is now out; pyldap has fulfilled its purpose.
If no urgent issues are found in python-ldap, I'll release pyldap 3.0.0 (dummy package) this week.
(Or next week, at latest)

items.title: Python-ldap.org is down. Unable to access documentation
items.body:
Hello, 

The website https://www.python-ldap.org/ is reporting an incompatible cipher mismatch for TLS.

items.title: Cannot import name '__version__'
items.body:
When I run import ldap, I get this error:-

```
----> 9 from pkginfo import __version__, __author__, __license__
     10
     11 import sys

ImportError: cannot import name '__version__'

```
I seem to be able to fix it by changing the code to:-

`from ldap.pkginfo import __version__, __author__, __license__`

which is basically the same as what's happening on line 20 later in the file anyway.

Has anybody else seen this?  If so, should I create a pull request with the fix?

Thanks
Chris

items.title: Update to python-ldap 2.5.1
items.body:
2.5.1 has been released with fixes for pyasn1 issue (PR #126).

http://python-ldap.cvs.sourceforge.net/viewvc/python-ldap/python-ldap/CHANGES?revision=1.484&view=markup

items.body:

I think it might work to build those wheels using Appveyor service: http://www.appveyor.com/

items.title: errno-related timeout raises non-LDAPError
items.body:
In case an `IndexError` is raised `_ldap_call`, the current logic does not re-raise the `LDAPError` but instead the `IndexError` breaking expectations further up.

See d8ac99c3c376ab6d3379b233acb7747db8dedd4f.

items.title: Is Python 3.2 supported?  pyldap uses missing symbol _PyUnicode_AsUTF8
items.body:
Hello!

It seems like pyldap does not support Python 3.2 (and presumably lower Python 3), because it is using the symbol `_PyUnicode_AsUTF8`.  At least from my perspective, I don't have a need for Python 3.2 or lower.  But still, the README and `setup.py` don't seem to mention that Python 3 needs 3.3 or later, so I wanted to report this!

Here's how I set up a Python 3.2 environment to verify this.  I'm running on macOS 10.12:

```
# If using MacPorts, bring in Python 3.2 and OpenLDAP.
# If not using MacPorts, then this assumes Python 3.2 is `python3.2`,
# and that the OpenLDAP headers are installed in system paths.
sudo port install openldap python32
TMPDIR=$(mktemp -d)
cd $TMPDIR
curl https://pypi.python.org/packages/47/15/7f9aabb1ce09d3dc5ecdff2f5a97e0a47f724fe8e398eff6a88626d0164c/setuptools-5.5.1.tar.gz#md5=86bbbfa732c234535316a7d74a49c6ad | tar -xzf -
curl https://pypi.python.org/packages/e4/3a/43fbf0c2ed567efd409d19968da3f373f83b99831090e3660be937f645a6/pyldap-2.4.37.tar.gz#md5=55b3b39d9c1c7837d80203a04d52c6a1 | tar -xzf -
cd setuptools-5.5.1
python3.2 setup.py build ; python3.2 setup.py install --user
cd ../pyldap-2.4.37

# The next two lines are only needed when MacPorts installed OpenLDAP.
# Otherwise, it tries to use OS LDAP headers, which doesn't work.
sed -i -e 's|library_dirs =|library_dirs = /opt/local/lib|' setup.cfg
sed -i -e 's|include_dirs =|include_dirs = /opt/local/include|' setup.cfg

python3.2 setup.py build ; python3.2 setup.py install --user
cd ..
rm -rf setuptools-5.5.1 pyldap-2.4.37
cd ~
rmdir $TMPDIR
```

The build and install goes fine; the error is triggered when loading `ldap`:

```
Karls-Mac-Mini-9346:~ akkornel$ python3.2
Python 3.2.6 (default, Oct 11 2016, 14:54:14) 
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 8.0.0 (clang-800.0.38)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ldap
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/akkornel/Library/Python/3.2/lib/python/site-packages/pyldap-2.4.37-py3.2-macosx-10.12-x86_64.egg/ldap/__init__.py", line 22, in <module>
    import _ldap
ImportError: dlopen(/Users/akkornel/Library/Python/3.2/lib/python/site-packages/pyldap-2.4.37-py3.2-macosx-10.12-x86_64.egg/_ldap.so, 2): Symbol not found: _PyUnicode_AsUTF8
  Referenced from: /Users/akkornel/Library/Python/3.2/lib/python/site-packages/pyldap-2.4.37-py3.2-macosx-10.12-x86_64.egg/_ldap.so
  Expected in: flat namespace
 in /Users/akkornel/Library/Python/3.2/lib/python/site-packages/pyldap-2.4.37-py3.2-macosx-10.12-x86_64.egg/_ldap.so
>>> ^D
```

It seems that `PyUnicode_AsUTF8` is present starting in Python 3.3; it is not listed in the equivalent page for Python 3.2.

https://docs.python.org/3.3/c-api/unicode.html#PyUnicode_AsUTF8
https://docs.python.org/3.2/c-api/unicode.html

In terms of current active releases, I'm guessing that only Debian wheezy would really be affected (it ships with Python 3.2).

items.title: Binding with digest-md5 fails right after success
items.body:
I'm using pyldap 2.4.37 installed via pip on a centOS 6 machine, with openldap 2.4.36

This is is how I'm trying to set up for digest-md5 auth, with the purpose if checking a user's credentials against the AD server for auth in a separate app.  

con = ldap.initialize('ldap://win2k8-ad.my.domain.com:389')
auth1 = ldap.sasl.sasl({ldap.sasl.CB_AUTHNAME: 'someuser', ldap.sasl.CB_PASS: 'thepassword'}, 'DIGEST-MD5')
auth2 = ldap.sasl.sasl({ldap.sasl.CB_AUTHNAME: 'Administrator', ldap.sasl.CB_PASS: 'thepassword'}, 'DIGEST-MD5')

Then, when doing binds, the first one will succeed:
con.sasl_interactive_bind_s("", auth1)
0

But doing it again *always* fails... even when done *right* afterward: 
con.sasl_interactive_bind_s("", auth1)
LDAPError - INVALID_CREDENTIALS: {'info': u'00090313: LdapErr: DSID-0C09052B, comment: AcceptSecurityContext error, data 0, v1772', 'desc': u'Invalid credentials'}

The only way to get it working again, is to bind with auth2, which succeeds... then *that* one always fails but you can then again bind with auth1.  

Further, waiting a while and then trying seems to just start giving "Local error":

LDAPError - LOCAL_ERROR: {'info': u'00090313: LdapErr: DSID-0C09052B, comment: AcceptSecurityContext error, data 0, v1772', 'errno': 107, 'desc': u'Local error'}

items.title: py3: firstname/lastname returned as bytes instead of str
items.body:
## Front matter
* I reported this issue at [Flask-AppBuilder/444](https://github.com/dpgaspar/Flask-AppBuilder/issues/444) but was sent here.
* We are authenticating against Microsoft AD Global Catalog, provided by Microsoft Server 2012 R2, which seems to be LDAPv3.
* pyldap==2.4.37

## Expected results
Querying `auth_ldap_firstname_field` and `auth_ldap_firstname_field` return firstname and lastname as strings.

## Actual results
The firstname and lastname fields are of type bytes. However, the email field is a string, as expected.

I tried all possible settings of bytes_mode, but with no success.

## Impact
When a new user registers in Superset (a Flask-Appbuilder app), the first- and lastname fields get populated with hex-encoded strings.

## Analysis
Adding a `.decode()` hotfixes the issue for me, but @dpgaspar from Flask-Appbuilder considers the root cause at pyldap.

items.title: AssertionError: Should return text, got bytes instead
items.body:
### Environment and problem

I just installed the latest Sentry 8.17.0 using their official docker image. These sentry instance should be configured to use ApacheDs as LDAP backend for user authentication and management. For this purpose, `django-auth-ldap` was installed as [authentication backend for django](https://pythonhosted.org/django-auth-ldap/install.html). I already got this working in the past with Active Directory, so it was no big issue to customize the configuration, so that it fits to an open LDAP directory server like ApacheDs is. 

But I ran into a big problem: I got the exception `AssertionError: Should return text, got bytes instead ('mail=user@example.com,ou=administratrators,ou=sub-users,ou=users,DC=myldap,DC=example,DC=com')` when I try to login using a LDAP user. This error seems strange for me: It contains the DN of my user (I tried to login with `user@example.com` here), so the LDAP connection is working, cause the DN was fetched from the server. The second surprising thing: Python says, that text was expected, but bytes were there. And the exception message contains the DN as a string?

I took a look at the source code file https://github.com/pyldap/pyldap/blob/master/Lib/ldap/ldapobject.py line 190:

```
if value is None:
      return value

    assert isinstance(value, text_type), "Should return text, got bytes instead (%r)" % (value,)
    if not self.bytes_mode:
      return value
    else:
      return value.encode('utf-8')

```

Python checks, if `value` is not a text type, then throw a error, which seems to stop the execution. This let my login fail and result in an internal server error. 

### Workaround 

We can define the distinguished name with a placeholder:

`AUTH_LDAP_USER_DN_TEMPLATE = 'mail=%(user)s,,ou=administratrators,ou=sub-users,ou=users,DC=myldap,DC=example,DC=com'`

In this case, we avoid the error: Since the DN can be generated, there is no need for the python lib to fetch it using a LDAP request. The problem is the lack of flexibility: You can't easily have the users spread across different OUs. And it's not possible to let them choose between different attributes as username (like username or email) for login. 

For this reason, I'm searching for a long term solution, that fixes this issue and let me drop the hard coded user DN. Being not a python developer, it's not exactly clear for me, where the root issue came from: Is there something wrong with the LDAP library? Or the django provider?

### Installed versions
django-auth-ldap (1.2.12)
pyldap (2.4.35.1)
python-ldap (2.4.39)


### UPDATE: Bug and (possible) solution

I simply tried to disable the `isinstance` line by commenting it out in `/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ldap/ldapobject.py`. After some incorporation, it seems to be an character set issue: Our input seems not well encoded in unicode, which is checked by text_type:

```
PY2 = bool(sys.version_info[0] <= 2)
if PY2:
  text_type = unicode
else:
  text_type = str
```

So this is a custom implementation of the [six library](https://pythonhosted.org/six/), which is designed to care about compatibility issues for python 2 and 3. The `decode` method provides a [way for converting a string to utf8](https://stackoverflow.com/a/19230566/3276634), with the ability to replace non utf8 characters. When we use this method first, the check wouldn't fail and LDAP without hard coded DN is working well. 

In the moment I'm using this workaround as custom modification, but also shared it in a pull request: https://github.com/pyldap/pyldap/pull/98 Would be nice to have this in one of the next releases, so that I can drop my custom modification. 

### Full stacktrace of the error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
sentry_1                |   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sentry/../django/core/handlers/base.py", line 112, in get_response
sentry_1                |     response = wrapped_callback(request, *callback_args, **callback_kwargs)
sentry_1                |   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sentry/../django/views/generic/base.py", line 69, in view
sentry_1                |     return self.dispatch(request, *args, **kwargs)
sentry_1                |   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sentry/../django/utils/decorators.py", line 29, in _wrapper
sentry_1                |     return bound_func(*args, **kwargs)
sentry_1                |   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sentry/../django/utils/decorators.py", line 99, in _wrapped_view
sentry_1                |     response = view_func(request, *args, **kwargs)
sentry_1                |   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sentry/../django/utils/decorators.py", line 25, in bound_func
sentry_1                |     return func(self, *args2, **kwargs2)
sentry_1                |   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sentry/web/frontend/base.py", line 187, in dispatch

sentry_1                |   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sentry/../django/views/decorators/cache.py", line 52, in _wrapped_view_func
```

items.title: Cant modify ldap objects if using pyldap
items.body:
I'm having an issue updating objects in my Ldap server
Openldap-2.4.40
CentOS 7

Server is refusing to modify objects if using pyldap, however it works if using python-ldap
Using pyldap==2.4.28

Seems like modlist.modifyModlist() from pyldap is not generating the correct output

The following script generates the modification list to be used by modify_s()
```
cat << _EOF_ > modifyModlist-test.py
import ldap
from ldap import modlist
import pprint
pp = pprint.PrettyPrinter(indent=4)
old = {'description': 'Old Description Test'}
new = {'description': 'New Description Test'}
ldif = modlist.modifyModlist(old, new)
pp.pprint(ldif)
_EOF_
```

Usig pyldap:
```
cd /tmp
virtualenv pyldap-env
. pyldap-env/bin/activate
pip install pyldap
python2 modifyModlist-test.py
deactivate
```
will produce: 
```
[   (1, 'description', None),
    (   0,
        'description',
        [   'N',
            'e',
            'w',
            ' ',
            'D',
            'e',
            's',
            'c',
            'r',
            'i',
            'p',
            't',
            'i',
            'o',
            'n',
            ' ',
            'T',
            'e',
            's',
            't'])]
```
which raises an error in my server, as you can see it generates a list for the 'description' value, and my ldap server thinks I'm trying to insert several description values, one for each member of the list.

However, using python-ldap it generates a different output:
```
cd /tmp
virtualenv python-ldap-env
. pyldap-env/bin/activate
pip install python-ldap
python2 modifyModlist-test.py
deactivate
```
will produce
```
[(1, 'description', None), (0, 'description', 'New Description Test')]
```
Whis is accepted by my server.

items.title: Release pyldap 2.4.33
items.body: Upstream python-ldap has released 2.4.33 yesterday, https://pypi.python.org/pypi/python-ldap/2.4.33

items.title: ldap.schema.tokenizer.split_tokens() performance issue
items.body:
The function ```split_tokens``` https://github.com/pyldap/pyldap/blob/master/Lib/ldap/schema/tokenizer.py#L10 is causing major performance issues in FreeIPA. After profiling a bunch of different requests and merging the performance stats, ```split_tokens``` sticks up as second most time consuming function in FreeIPA. Nearly a quarter of the total request time of 24 distinct JSON RPC requests is spent in that function. A more detailed analysis is available in FreeIPA ticket https://fedorahosted.org/freeipa/ticket/6679

I like to explore how we could improve the function. I have some ideas (rewrite, regular expression, Cython) but I haven't grokked the tokenizer yet.

items.title: Searching for membership in nested AD groups returns zero results
items.body:
I'm  trying to run a search in Active Directory with this filter, which should return all of the groups that I am a member of, including nested groups:

```
(member:1.2.840.113556.1.4.1941:=CN=Whalen, Sean,OU=Users,OU=Users and Groups,DC=redacted,DC=net)
```

This filter is described in https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa746475(v=vs.85).aspx

This works fine in powershell, but instantly returns 0 results in python-ldap

Then I tried

```
(member:1.2.840.113556.1.4.1941:=CN=Whalen\5c, Sean,OU=Users,OU=Users and Groups,DC=redacted,DC=net)
```

That ran for about 10 seconds in python-ldap, and returned 0 results. Powershell returned 0 results instantly.

The reverse query (finding all nested members of a group) works fine

```
(memberof:1.2.840.113556.1.4.1941:=cn=Group1,OU=groupsOU,DC=x)
```

Any ideas about what's going wrong/how to fix it?

items.title: using pyldap with ldappool
items.body:
Thanks for your work with this project! I had a hopefully quick question.

Our project (https://github.com/openstack/keystone) currently uses python-ldap and we're looking to make it python3 compatible. pyldap seems like the logical choice, but there is one hiccup in the plan. We currently also use ldappool (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ldappool/) to pool connections, we've received positive feedback that this does help improve performance and would like to keep using ldappool (or a similar mechanism). Do you know if we could use pyldap with ldappool? Or have an alternate suggestion? Have you had similar requests for this feature before? Thanks in advance!

items.title: Version numbering for pyldap fix releases?
items.body:
We have a clear policy for version numbering from upstream versions.

However, how should we number releases that fix bugs in our fork, thus happening between upstream releases?

Should we go with `(upstream).1` for our first bugfix on top of an upstream version?
For instance, the fixes on `2.4.25` would be in `2.4.25.1`. This seems compatible with PEP440 (https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/).

What do you think?

items.title: Modlist tuple length mismatch on Python 2
items.body: When adding entries, modlist attribute is supposed to be a list of 2-tuples, but it internally uses _unbytesify_modlist function, which expects a list of 3-tuples, leading to "Too many values to unpack" error. Happens on Python 2 only, on Python3 the function is a no-op.

items.title: ldap.schema.subentry.SubSchema broken in Python 3
items.body: The SubSchema class constructor expects a dictionary returned by LDAP search as its first argument. With Python 3, attribute values in the dictionary are bytes, but the SubSchema class expects str, and thus fails to parse the dictionary.

items.title: ldap.schema.tokenizer.extract_tokens() uses dict.has_key()
items.body: The extract_tokens() function of the ldap.schema.tokenizer module uses has_key() method on dict, which is not available in Python 3.

items.title: Forks and branches
items.body:
I like to raise the issue of forks and branches. pyldap is a fork my fork, which I forked from Raphaël's personal git repos, which itself is yet another fork of a CVS repository. A couple of branches are involved, too. It's too confusing.

I like to restart with a clean slate and remove my fork out of the picture. We also should come with a plan how to pull updates from upstream's CVS. Git's cvs importer can pull updates from CVS as long as the CVS import branch contains **only** CVS commits.
## suggestions
- have a dedicated `cvs` branch that contains only CVS commits. In both Raphaël's and my repository that's is currently the `master` branch. Action: rename `master` to `cvs`.
- new development happens in `master`. Let's rename the `py3` branch to `master`.
- regularly pull changes from CVS into the `cvs` branch and rebase master

```
git cvsimport -d:pserver:anonymous@python-ldap.cvs.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/python-ldap python-ldap -o cvs
```

items.title: Define upgrade path from upstream's python-ldap
items.body:
The upstream version uses the name `ldap`.

Two options here:
- Keep the name
- Install under `pyldap`

**Keeping the name**:
- Requires backwards compatibility
- Eases merging back upstream
- Prevents users from having both versions side by side

**Using another name**:
- Allows for updated APIs
- Allows two versions living in the same system
- Requires shuffling files around and lots of useless renames

items.title: Define backwards compatibility rules regarding encoding
items.body:
The long-term goal of this repository is to be merged back into the upstream python-ldap package.

However, the python-ldap API doesn't feel natural under Python3, mostly with its encoding handling (it uses bytes everywhere, even when unicode strings could be used).

From the [RFCs](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4511#section-4.1.2), some fields _MUST_ be encoded as UTF-8, thus represented as unicode under Py2 / str under Py3.

This issue appears mostly on base DNs in filters and in return distinguished names:

``` python
# In Py2:
>>> base = u"ou=people,dc=example,dc=org"
>>> results = connection.search_ext(base.encode('utf-8'), scope=ldap.SCOPE_SUBTREE)
>>> results[0][0]  # results is a list of (dn, data)
b'uid=rbarrois,ou=people,dc=example,dc=org'
>>> results[0][1].keys()[0]
b'distinguisedName'
```
- For filters, since data is fed from the calling program to python-ldap, it is simple to support both unicode and bytes and convert as needed
- For output, we must decide on a type - either bytes or unicode.

If we want third party libraries integrating python-ldap to use the same code on both Py2 and Py3, we have only a few options:
- Keep the Py2, bytes-only API for Py3
- Change the Py2 API from python-ldap's version
- Use a new object to represent "modern" connections

The goal is to be able to write the following code:

``` python
# In Py3 ("" for str, b'' for bytes)
>>> base = "ou=people,dc=example,dc=org"
>>> results = connection.search_ext(base, scope=ldap.SCOPE_SUBTREE)
>>> results[0]
("uid=rbarrois,ou=people,dc=example,dc=org", {
    "uid": [b'rbarrois'],
    "picture": [b'XXX.UZYGFUYGFUEY...'],
})

# In Py2 (u"" for unicode, '' for bytes)
>>> base = u"ou=people,dc=example,dc=org"
>>> results = connection.search_ext(base, scope=ldap.SCOPE_SUBTREE)
>>> results[0]
(u"uid=rbarrois,ou=people,dc=example,dc=org", {
    u"uid": ['rbarrois'],
    u"picture": ['XXX.UZYGFUYGFUEY...'],
})
```
